content.p: Decide whether each of the following statements is a valid conclusion or an invalid conclusion, based on the study:

question.body: 1. The results do not reject the null hypothesis:

response.feedback: Correct. When the results are "not statistically significant," it means we don’t have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis, because any difference in the study was probably just by chance. In fact, the p-value is the probability of that chance difference, and a p-value of .214 is considerably larger than the traditional .05 level below which we would begin to reject the null hypothesis.

Incorrect. Remember that "not statistically significant" means we don’t have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis, because any difference in the study was probably just by chance. In fact, the p-value is the probability of that chance difference, and notice that the p-value of .214 is considerably larger than the traditional .05 level below which we would begin to reject the null hypothesis.

question.body: 2. The results provide enough evidence to accept the null hypothesis:

response.feedback: Incorrect. Remember that we never "accept" the null hypothesis. Although it’s true that the lack of statistical significance in the study indicates we don’t have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis, that doesn’t mean the null has been proved true. It means the study might not have been sensitive enough, so the null hypothesis should be remain the default conclusion until more evidence is gathered.

Correct. We never "accept" the null hypothesis. In the case of the study described, the lack of statistical significance means there wasn’t sufficiently surprising evidence against the null, so the null hypothesis should merely remain the default conclusion until more evidence is gathered.

question.body: 3. The results indicate that it must be true that the nationwide proportion, p, of support for the current administration is equal to 40%:

response.feedback: Incorrect. Remember that we never "prove" the null hypothesis. Although it’s true that the lack of statistical significance in the study indicates we don’t have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis, that doesn’t mean the null is true; the alternative hypothesis might actually be true, and it might simply be that the study wasn’t sensitive enough to detect a real difference.

Correct. We never "prove" the null hypothesis. In the case of the study described, the lack of statistical significance in the study indicates we don’t have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis, but that doesn’t mean the null is true; the alternative hypothesis might actually be true, and it might simply be that the study wasn’t sensitive enough to detect a real difference.

question.body: 4. The results indicate that the nationwide proportion, p, of support for the current administration might be greater than 40%, but the sample size in the study might have been too small to detect a statistically significant difference:

response.feedback: Correct. Even though the null hypothesis can’t be rejected by this study, the alternative hypothesis might actually be true; the study might simply not have been sensitive enough to detect the difference.

Incorrect. It’s true that the null hypothesis can’t be rejected by this study, because the relatively large p-value meant the results of the study weren’t statistically significant. But remember that when we "don’t reject the null hypothesis," the alternative hypothesis might actually be true; the study might simply not have been sensitive enough to detect the difference.
